Award.AwardTitle: Negative Curvature in Fiber Bundles and Counting Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Among the many techniques available for exploring complicated geometric systems, often two of the most fruitful are (1) decomposing related structures into their basic building blocks and (2) sampling from those systems to determine their typical behavior. For example, to understand a high dimensional geometric object, one can study the various ways that object fibers (i.e., can be build out of simpler, lower dimensional pieces which are arranged in a predictable way). Even if a complete understanding of the object may be out of reach, one can attempt to comprehend its properties "on average." In this project, the PI seeks to apply similar principles to the study of geometrically significant groups via their action on naturally associated spaces. This pursuit brings to bear methods from geometry, topology, dynamics, and group theory, and seeks to not only understand these objects in an abstract sense, but to produce tractable models which allow for quantitative understanding.

In more detail, the PI will carry out projects that investigate the geometry and topology of hyperbolic bundles as well as study geometrically motivated counting problems in finitely generated groups. In the classical setting of a hyperbolic 3-manifold fibering over the circle, this project builds on a program to study the extent to which the veering triangulation (a certain combinatorial construction) effectively encodes the manifold's geometry and topology. Inspired by the elegant nature of these triangulations, the PI will construct a canonical ideal simplicial complex in the setting of free-by-cyclic groups; a setting where a single topological object controlling the group's algebraic decompositions is currently lacking. Finally, the PI will study the "typical" geometry of fibered manifolds, free-by-cyclic groups, and representations of hyperbolic groups. A common thread throughout these investigations will be to demonstrate the extent to which negative curvature features are persistent and, in the appropriate sense, generic.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied geometric and dynamical structures of spaces and their symmetries with a special focus on dimensions one, two, and three. In these low dimensions, there are often deep connections between geometry, topology, and algebra, and understanding these interactions was a central theme of the supported research.


The PI was largely guided by the following interrelated questions: (1) How can complex dynamical systems on three-dimensional spaces be understood by decomposing the space into simpler building blocks that are assembled according to the dynamics? (2) Can we understand the algebraic symmetries of an object by generating and studying "random" examples? (3) Do these random examples satisfy well-known statistical laws, like being distributed along a bell curve at large scale?


In joint work with his collaborators, the PI answered these questions for objects that are central in the fields of geometric group theory and geometric topology. With M. Landry and Y. Minsky, the PI studied certain flows on three-dimensional manifolds and introduced a new algebraic invariant known as the veering polynomial. This polynomial is combinatorially defined but encodes dynamical properties of these flows and generalizes work of McMullen. In separate joint work with D. Futer and W. Worden, the PI showed that the combinatorics used to define the veering polynomial (so-called veering triangulations) generically fail to capture the geometry of the underlying space in a certain precise sense. With C. Leininger, Y. Minsky, and J. Souto, the PI studied other connections between these flows and the geometry of the space of cross-sections, generalizing a result of Farb--Leininger--Margalit. These projects all address question (1) from above.


To address questions (2) and (3), the PI has studied several models of randomness in geometric group theory. With I. Kapovich, J. Maher, and C. Pfaff, he investigated randomly generated algebraic symmetries (i.e., automorphisms of the free groups) showing that these have a certain "singularity" structure, thereby answering questions of Handel--Mosher and Bestvina. Finally, with I. Gekhtman and G. Tiozzo, the PI studied the asymptotic distribution of certain quantities connected to symmetries of negatively curved spaces. One outcome of this research was a proof of the Chas--Li--Maskit conjecture, which states that the lengths of geodesics on a hyperbolic surface, when sampled with respect to their word length, are approximately normally distributed. This is the basis for more general central limit theorems also established by the PI with Gekhtman and Tiozzo.

In addition to the supported research, the PI has also been involved with graduate student mentoring and undergraduate outreach. This includes co-organizing summer reading groups from 2017-2021 on various topics in geometric topology, leading nine independent studies with graduate students since 2018, and both formally and informally mentoring other graduate students and postdocs.
